If they made it easier to pass a GPU through to the VMs I'd want to give it a try. But without that ability it's pretty much pointless since I do a lot of GPU work and gaming, and dual booting is too much of a pain. The day I can run Windows in a VM with full GPU access, without having to cut the GPU off from the host, will be a glorious day indeed.

@Musickiller: Couldn't you achieve something similar to this using [Qubes OS][1]? You run apps inside sandboxes and VMs, controlling what they have access to. That way you place the risky apps (like a web browser that is vulnerable to exploitation) inside a sandbox and it can't access resources you don't want it to.

[1]: https://www.qubes-os.org/tour/
It's theoretically possible though. You also have all the files yourself so you could skim them manually in the mean time.

Yeah, I've seen it.
I'll get to merging it into DZM.

@Edantes:  I did it! :D

After you make your .pac file, drag&drop it onto Firefox and let Firefox open it in a tab. This will give you a "file:///" URL. You then go into Firefox's Proxy settings and use that URL as the "Automatic proxy configuration URL". Click "OK", and *tada*, you can now use shortened Zeronet URLs!

There's no surefire way, as you can only see peers you're connected to, but if you drag the Zeronet button in the top-right corner to the left on any of the popular sites like "Hello Zeronet" and "ZeroMe", you can see how many peers you're connected to for those sites. I'm currently seeing 830 peers for "Hello Zeronet", but that's only the peers my client knows about, and also doesn't count all the people that are currently offline.
@Kaffie:  Yep, I was wondering why I was clicking and nothing was happening XD

Ah, seems to be working now. All I need now is a follow button so that everything shows up in "Hello Zeronet". That or have a notification system implemented so that my computer at least beeps or something when I get a reply.

I've been using it with Firefox for Android. And yeah, it doesn't scale for smaller screens. Though that's really not a primary focus of development anyway considering that you can't run Zeronet on Mobile without doing a lot of work, like running a VM or setting up Python in Android. Most people on mobile are using a proxy or tunneling to their home installation. Someone could create a modified ZeroMe for mobile though, in a similar way I made Dark ZeroMe.
It needs an auto-refresh, and maybe a way to save the entered username so I don't have to re-enter it every time I reload the page.

@Edantes: You can manually clone a site by copying the data from its site folder to a blank site you created through the Zeronet command line. Just make sure you don't overwrite the "content.json" in your new site's root directory. Then you just wipe the data directory and start tweaking whatever files you want. That's how I made Dark ZeroMe.
Do you have Android Device Manager enabled?

@Musickiller: It's a built-in function of Play Services that allows you to remotely track, ring, lock, and wipe your phone. It should be enabled by default these days, but if not go to Settings--> Security --> Device Administrators, and make sure "Android Device Manager" is enabled. Then you just go to https://www.google.com/android/devicemanager and login with your Google account.


@weakish: There are third-party alternatives as well if you're paranoid about Google. Though that point is pretty much moot if you're already using Google Play and Play Services.

Since Microsoft is porting everything like .Net to Linux now and open-sourcing everything, maybe my time stuck with Windows will end in the near future. Really I just need my games and video software to run on Linux and I'd switch back in a heartbeat. That or a VM with Graphics switching, so I can just run Windows in a box when I want to play a game. So far you have to dedicate a graphics card to a VM in order to get it to work in there, which makes it unusable by the Host system until you reverse the changes and reboot.

Wow, I don't remember LVM being that hard to pull off. Especially when I used the "system-config-lvm" gui. My biggest annoyance is that "system-config-lvm" isn't included on most LiveCDs, so I have the extra step of installing it everytime I want to edit my primary partition :P

Then again, I wasn't using LVM with Arch, so maybe there's some "excitement" that I'm missing...

Catch = 1048560 / âˆš(âˆš(16711680 / CatchValue)) = (220 - 24) / âˆš(âˆš((224 - 216) / CatchValue))

No wait, that's the catch equation in 6th gen Pokemon.
Well, at the rate things are going, it does sound like you're enjoying this in a twisted way... XD

If LVM worked with more than just Linux then I'd use it for everything. I love using it with my VMs as it makes expanding the storage real easy when I'm using multiple partitions in a VM. It even allows me to store my VMs across multiple drives/partitions on the host PC. Just store one virtualdisk file on one drive, store the other on another drive, mount both of them, format LVM and then combine! 

Sure you can generally expand a virtualdisk file if you run out of space, but then you have to deal with the existing partitions and whether the one you want bigger is easily enlarged, and you're also stuck with a single massive multi-gigabyte file to deal with as well.

@Shellbound: For me it works for convenience sake in a VM. If for example I had partitions A/B/C but wanted to add space for A, repartitioning everything while being careful of data loss is a pain. But with LVM I just have to format the new expanded diskspace for LVM and then I can easily add it to partition A. LVM also works out of the box on many Distros.
@Shellbound: That's not the scenario I was describing at all.

@Musickiller: I don't understand why you'd have difficulty. It just involves flashing a ZIP in recovery and installing an APK. Pretty much the same level of difficulty as setting up Root. Though sometimes, especially with Samsung products, you need to find a modded version of Xposed for your device. But that's usually pretty easy to find by searching in Google or XDA.

There is really zero benefit to anyone by posting them here. Sure a combined post with a bunch of torrents you find interesting is fine, but there's no reason to just spam them.

@Rapapobre:  You may not like my opinion, but until there's a way for users to filter out content on ZeroMe or to join groups of specific topics, your torrent posts were flooding the Everything feed on ZeroMe. That flooding meant other people who posted things would have trouble getting their posts noticed unless they were already established users and had followers. If you want to make a daily post of all the torrents you've added to ZeroTorrent that's fine. You can make it really long and it won't bother anyone or push other posts. But flooding ZeroMe with individual posts for every torrent you want to share is very rude.

And yes that's my opinion, but the whole point of Zeronet is that we can express our opinions right? At least I'm not insulting you and cursing. I won't comment on your posting methods in the future, but I at least wanted to convey that your posting methods weren't being appreciated by everyone.

@P2P: Zeronet definitely helps with connectivity. Once some peers in China manage to download most of a Zite or File it can then be shared locally with other Chinese users without them having to go back over an ocean to get it again. Actually, that'd be a great thing for @Nofish: to cover. Zeronet helps connectivity to content in regions where internet connections to other countries are slow and unreliable. It'll be even better once Zeronet can ditch its reliance on trackers.

Heck, Zeronet would be great for people on the Moon or Mars since they can still interact with sites even if content is loading slowly in the background.

No javascript based translation currently exists. Any existing tools either rely on installing a local app or using a third-party API that goes through the clearnet.

If you really want convenient translation, just get any of the many existing addons for Chrome and Firefox. I personally prefer "S3.Google Translator" for Firefox as it provides simple select-click-and-translate functionality, with the translation appearing in a nice popup that I can tweak the results with. Sure it sends the text to Google, but it's better than no translation.

@Mynameislegion: Well, I've already used the ZeroHello search to find old posts that had useful information, so it is useful. And besides, I don't like the idea that stuff is simply thrown away(which is why I support things like Archive.org). People should have the option to keep things backed up. Setting files as optional would be clean and solve the space issue for most people that don't want older files. Perhaps adding an ability to ZeroNet that lets you easily cleanup optional files that are older than a certain number of days would also be useful for people that don't want to keep really old things around. It'd also be nice if I could choose which optional files to keep around, so I could say keep all the text around but delete the pictures which hog a lot of space.

You can't embed videos. ZeroNet still isn't very video friendly. There's been a few experiments with WebTorrents, IPFS, and a project called ZeroMux that uses a python tool to break large files and videos into chunks ahead of time and then has a custom embeded player that will properly request the chunks and mux them on the fly for playback in any standard ZeroNet install.

PS: Posting/Embedding clearnet videos in a Zite is frowned on unless you state before hand that it's a clearnet link.

As a creator of a ZeroMe clone I can tell you that I never see any user data, ever. The reason for that is because ZeroMe is actually just a front-end to the Hubs, where all the user data is actually kept. It runs locally on your computer where your local ZeroNet is in charge of updating the data in the Hubs you access. So you shouldn't be scared of ZeroMe clones, since the data is controlled by the Hubs. But you shouldn't be scared of hubs either. Since everything you post is signed locally by your private key, so any modifications can easily be detected by the public key you share. 

Your ZeroNet private key never leaves your PC.

Well, there's the very alpha [ZeroMusic](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MusicXkuN2pk5hRdmroeyaCLDJtzTicpB/). It can take a bit for a track to load though since it has to find a peer with the file and sometimes they're on TOR which is slow. There's also no playlist or station functions. Just pick a single song, wait for it to download, and then play. 27GB+ of music has been added. Naturally you only seed the files you've downloaded unless you decide to be generous and download the entire 27GB+ of music. Once you've downloaded a track it'll stay on your computer to be played at any time until deleted manually.

>The Great Dictator was Chaplinâ€™s first film with dialogue. Chaplin plays both a little Jewish barber, living in the ghetto, and Hynkel, the dictator ruler of Tomainia. In his autobiography Chaplin quotes himself as having said: â€œOne doesnâ€™t have to be a Jew to be anti Nazi. All one has to be is a normal decent human being.â€
>
>Chaplin and Hitler were born within a week of one another. â€œThere was something uncanny in the resemblance between the Little Tramp and Adolf Hitler, representing opposite poles of humanity, â€ writes Chaplin biographer David Robinson, reproducing an unsigned article from The Spectator dated 21st April 1939:
>â€œProvidence was in an ironical mood when, fifty years ago this week, it was ordained that Charles Chaplin and Adolf Hitler should make their entry into the world within four days of each otherâ€¦.Each in his own way has expressed the ideas, sentiments, aspirations of the millions of struggling citizens ground between the upper and the lower millstone of society. (â€¦) Each has mirrored the same reality â€“ the predicament of the â€œlittle manâ€ in modern society. Each is a distorting mirror, the one for good, the other for untold evil.â€
>
>Chaplin spent many months drafting and re-writing the speech for the end of the film, a call for peace from the barber who has been mistaken for Hynkel. Many people criticized the speech, and thought it was superfluous to the film. Others found it uplifting. Regrettably Chaplinâ€™s words are as relevant today as they were in 1940.

Nofish added that restriction after somebody uploaded the PDF. He says while testing he doesn't want people to upload a bunch of small files, like what PDFs and MP3s usually are. Though the other restriction of minimum filesize of 10MB should've been enough for that. There's nothing stopping you from manually cloning ZeroUp and removing the restriction for yourself though.
You should upload some of them to ZeroUp. I'd do it myself, but my upload currently sucks right now.
Videos are downloaded as you stream them. But you can click the "+Seed" button on ZeroUp to just tell it to download the whole file. Useful if the download is slow and you don't want to sit around.
ZeroUp really needs filters, sorts, and search soon. It's way too clogged with a bunch of random stuff now.

I think people are mostly complaining about US cable ISPs that treat customers like shit, have virtual monopolies in many areas, and some even have stupid caps that they'll either charge tons of money for overages or even cut off your service because of your "misbehaving".
